boardgame.description: Description from BoardgameNews_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;In Agricola, you're a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you'll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood, or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;The game supports many levels of complexity, mainly through the use (or non-use) of two of its main types of cards, Minor Improvements and Occupations. In the beginner's version (called the Family Variant in the U.S. release), these cards are not used at all. For advanced play, the U.S. release includes three levels of both types of cards; Basic (E-deck), Interactive (I-deck), and Complex (K-deck), and the rulebook encourages players to experiment with the various decks and mixtures thereof. Aftermarket decks such as the Z-Deck and the L-Deck also exist._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game rounds occurring in 6 stages, with a Harvest at the end of each stage (after Rounds 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14)._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and spouse) and thus can take two turns, or actions, per round. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you'll have more and more: first thing in a round, a new action card is flipped over._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Problem: Each action can be taken by only one player each round, so it's important to do some things with high preference._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he/she may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. Speaking of which, there are countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it's a good choice to stay on course, and sometimes it is better to react to your opponents' actions._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

This is the original German version. Box has some wear. Paste-ups for key playing cards and beginner deck (via card inserts and sleeves).

Description of Game (quoted from box back): “Players start the game with two family members living in a two-room wooden hut. In each round, each member of their family may choose one action. If they collect wood and reed, they can extend their hut and then add to their family. Family growth allows additional actions, but has the disadvantage that more food must be produced. And to get food, the players plow fields and plant seeds. The planted grain and vegetables are harvested during the Harvest, when animals breed as well. To raise animals, pastures must be fenced to allow sheep, wild boar and cattle to graze. Occupations or Improvements can ensure a family’s upkeep. Each of these cards allows the player a small advantage in the game. Victory Points are earned when players renovate their wooden hut to a clay hut and later even a stone house. But everything else to do with balancing food requirements or making every day life a little more comfortable can earn Victory Points – especially Family growth. Each game uses a different group of the 166 different Occupation cards and 146 different Improvements, ensuring that no two games are exactly alike. Additional rules for a Solo game and a shortened Family game ensure appropriate challenges for each gaming table.” Game Contains: # 9 double-sided boards # 138 Good tokens # 36 Food tokens # 54 Animal cubes # 25 Person tokens # 75 fences # 20 stables # 24 Hut tiles # 33 Stone house/Field tiles # 3 Guest/Claim markers # 9 Multiplication tokens # 1 scoring pad # 1 Game rules # 1 Starting player marker # 360 cards # 2 Deck cards # 169 Occupation cards # 149 Improvement cards # 14 Round cards # 16 Action cards # 5 Begging cards # 5 Summary cards

Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo. Contents: 360 cards, over 300 wooden components, 50+ tiles, 9 boards, tokens, scoring pad. No. of players: 1-5 Ages: 12+ Playing time: 120-180 minutes

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) Designed by Uwe Rosenberg In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo.

Z-Man Games (ZMG 7026) In Agricola (Latin for _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;farmer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;), you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;re a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats? Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over. Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do. Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo.
Only been played once.

THIS ITEM CAN ONLY BE PURCHASED BY Alex V (Vila), AS HE WON IT IN A GEEKLIST AUCTION. (If you are not him, please do not try to buy this item.) NOTE: This is NOT for the complete game of Agricola! Rather, it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s for the original wooden (and cardboard) bits for the resources (wood, clay, stone, reed), grain, vegetables, animals (sheep, boar, cattle) and food from the base game. I have replaced these in my set with the animeeples, grain/vegemeeples and the similar wooden bits for resources and food, so I thought I would offer these originals to any interested party. WHAT YOU GET: 238 bits! 33 round (dark) brown Wood counters, 27 round _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;red_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; (light brown, actually) Clay counters, 15 round white Reed counters, 18 round _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;grey_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; (black, actually) Stone counters, 27 round yellow Grain counters, 18 round orange Vegetable counters, 21 white cubes for Sheep, 18 black cubes for Boars, 15 brown cubes for Cattle, and 36 round yellow cardboard tokens for Food. All the bits are wood, except for the cardboard Food counters. BONUS!: An additional 60 even-better bits! I will also include Mayday Games_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039; Wooden Farm Animal Set (Animeeples For Agricola). This bonus is a set of wooden animals - 25 sheep, 20 boars and 15 cattle - produced by Mayday Games for use in Agricola. Note that these Animeeples are in addition to the original cubes-as-animals from the original game listed in the previous paragraph. Why It_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s Cool: A total of almost 300 bits! You could double your current supply so you don_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;t have to use the _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot;multiplier chits_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_quot; while playing Agricola. Or, you could use them as bits in another game or your favourite prototype. Condition: Excellent.

You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?
Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14). Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over.
Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do.
Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo.

There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over.
Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s important to do some things with high preference. Each player also starts with a hand of 7 Occupation cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 Minor Improvement cards (of more than 140 total) that he may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. This amounts to countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s a good choice to stay on course, sometimes you better react on what your opponents do.
Agricola can also be played without cards (family game) and can even be played solo.
